div1.p: Thompson reports on the sanitary condition of the water supply in Great Britain. Barber provides information regarding malarial conditions in Louisiana. LePrince discusses mosquito control efforts in Tennessee and Alabama.

PUBLIC HEALTH ENGINEERING ABSTRACTS
div1.p:
SCRAPING WATER MAINS, HELENSBURGH, SCOTLAND. Jas. W. Stirling. Surveyor,
Vol. 65, No. 1691, June 13, 1924. p. 554.

The water supply of Helensburgh is obtained from the Ballyvoulin Burn,
3 miles distant from the reservoirs. The water, after settlement, does
not require filtration and the existing filter beds, which are inadequate
to deal with the present consumption, are to be emptied and used as storage
tanks. Trouble has been experienced with the growth of a variety of chara
in the reservoirs, necessitating occasional emptying and cleaning. The weed
does not flourish on the pitched surface of the banks, in those parts oc-
casionally exposed to air and sun, or at depths greater than 12 feet. Greater
difficulty is caused by the growth in the mains of a fairly soft nodule of
rusty appearance composed of hydrated ferric oxide and vegetable matter. In
one instance a 5-in. pipe on a gradient of 1 in 7 was rendered impenetrable
to water under pressure of 75 lbs. Surfaces completely coated with nodules
1-1 1/4 inches in thickness are frequently encountered. The two g-in. pipes
which convey the water from the fountain head to the reservoirs were scraped
in 1909 and in 1920, the capacity being increased from 40,000 gals. per hour
to 52,500 in the former year and from 35,000 to 51,000 in the latter. In 1920
the scraping was carried out with a Glenfield scraper at a cost of 3d. per
yard. The town pipes were scraped by hand, 85 yards in each direction being
dealt with from one opening, at an approximate cost of 3 d. per yard per inch
in diameter. The scraping considerably more than doubled the discharge from
certain hydrants and the day pressure was increased from 45 lbs. to 82 and
the night pressure from 85 to 106. The per capita consumption is 70 gals.
per day for domestic and 5 gals. for other purposes.
Rudolph E. Thompson.

VARIATIONS IN CONSUMPTION OF WATER IN TOWNS. John Bowman, Surveyor, Vol. 65,
No. 1693, June 27, 1924. p. 589.

The per capita consumption of water in 58 areas in Great Britain is given,
with a few statistics for American Cities for comparison. The consumption in
the areas quoted ranges from 14.26 to 70 gals. per day, 29 being lower than
25 gals. and 29 higher. Eighteen of the 29 higher consumptions are in towns
in Scotland, this being due to the larger number of fittings per house as
compared with towns in England. A table is included showing the results of
measurements recently made in Edinburgh of the consumption in different types
of districts and in various institutions.
Rudolph E. Thompson.

OPERATION RECORDS FOR SMALL WATER WORKS. Earle L. Waterman, Associate Professor
of Sanitary Engineering, University of Iowa. Canadian Engineer, Vol. 46, No.
20, May 13, 1924. p. 521-2.

The value of water works operation records is emphasized and the existing
situation, particularly in the State of Iowa is discussed. Details that should
be embodied in the records are reviewed and the many ways in which such records
may be used to advantage are pointed out.
Rudolph E. Thompson.

MALARIA, OTHER INSECT BORNE DISEASES AND INSECTS.
PAGE TWENTY-SIX.

MALARIA IN THE SEVENTH DISTRICT OF LOUISIANA. M. A. Barber, U.S. Public Health Service. New Orleans Medical & Surgical Journal, Vol. 77, No. 1,
July, 1924. p. 16-20.

The Seventh Congressional District includes a group of parishes in south-
west Louisiana, in some of which rice is cultivated extensively. In the rice
fields, covered with water during a large part of the summer, myriads of
Anopheles are produced. The immense area under irrigation, would make pro-
hibitive the cost of preventing the Anopheles production. In spite of large
numbers of Anopheles the malaria rate of this region is not high. The examina-
tion of the blood of 1235 school children gave a parasite index of only 3.2%.
The spleen rate of 190 school-boys was only 3.7%. In both sorts of survey many
children from outside the rice region are included, some of whom gave a much
higher malaria rate than those in the rice region. A search for malaria cases
in the vicinity of Crowley, La., a work in which the physicians of Crowley
cooperated, yielded during 1923 only about 90 cases in which parasites could
be found in the blood. According to the testimony of physicians malaria has
been rapidly decreasing during recent years.

Houses in the rice region are fairly well built, a large proportion of
them screened and bed nets are commonly used in unscreened houses. The rural
population is fairly well-to-do and the negro population is largely confined
to towns. It is quite possible that the relatively high general standard of
living is an important factor in the prevention of malaria in the rice region
notwithstanding the abundance of Anopheline carriers. In the term “standard
of living” is included more adequate treatment of the sick and some knowledge
of the method by which malaria is transmitted. The important question is
raised as to whether a very moderate rise in the general standard of living
may not greatly reduce the malaria rate. It is emphasized that the improve-
ment should be general. A neglected group may harbor carriers and tend to
vitiate the whole community.
M. A. Barber.
MALARIA CONTROL AS APPROACHED BY AN ALABAMA INDUSTRIAL CORPORATION. C. H.

Kibbey, M.D., Director of Sanitation, Tennessee Coal, Iron & R.R.Co. Transactions
Fourth Annual Conference Malaria Field Workers, Chattanooga, Tenn., November 14-16,
1922. Public Health Bulletin No. 137. p.25-40.

The Tennessee Coal, Iron & Railroad Company has demonstrated that conser-
vation of the health of employees indemnifies large employers of man power.

Large areas of Naias flexilis, which were responsible for much anopheles breed-
ing in a large impounding reservoir, were successfully eradicated. The method used
is described.

The destruction of mosquito larvae by the wave action from a power launch is
reported as being entirely successful. Vegetation, along the water margin which
is calculated to interfere with violence of wave motion, is removed. Daily trips
with the motor boat are made around a pond having some 22 miles of shore line.
Control is considered 100% perfect without the use of other larvacidal measures.

The use of fish as a malaria control measure can no more be left in the hands
of the public than can any other sanitary procedure. Removal of vegetation, other
than some of the algae, not considered necessary to effective fish control, es-
pecially if game fish abound. Predatory fish apt to herd gambusia into that por-
tion of the water where they are most needed.

A campaign to control malaria through mosquito reproduction should include
the control of the pestiferous mosquitoes also. Success of health work is largely
dependent upon the attitude of the public toward the work. No advertising is
better calculated to increase the popularity of a health department that is the
eradication of mosquitoes.
